Summary: The proposal introduces Adaptive Model-Based Priors (AMBP), a novel framework for improving sample efficiency in reinforcement learning by dynamically adjusting the reliance on model-based predictions based on uncertainty estimates. The method integrates uncertainty-aware model rollouts, dynamic horizon adaptation, and adaptive blending. The experiment plan includes validation of uncertainty estimation, testing dynamic horizon adaptation, benchmarking sample efficiency, ablation studies, and real-world feasibility testing.
Strengths: Innovative integration of multiple components (uncertainty-aware rollouts, dynamic horizon adaptation, adaptive blending).
Weaknesses: Lacks detailed discussion on computational overhead and potential mitigation strategies.
Specific metrics for evaluating the adaptive blending mechanism could be more explicitly defined.
Potential technical challenges in real-world deployment are not fully explored.
Questions: How will the computational overhead of uncertainty estimation and dynamic horizon adaptation be managed?
What specific metrics will be used to evaluate the effectiveness of the adaptive blending mechanism?
How will the proposed method handle non-stationary environments where the dynamics change over time?
Limitations: Potential computational overhead from uncertainty estimation and dynamic horizon adaptation.
Scalability to high-dimensional or complex environments may be limited.
Real-world deployment may introduce additional noise and uncertainty not accounted for in simulations.
